awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Smart Stent for Post-Endovascular Aneurysm Repair Surveillance
awd_abstract_narration:
An abdominal aortic aneurysm is the most commonly diagnosed arterial aneurysm that is an abnormal bulge on the aorta associated with the gradual thinning of the vessel wall. With mortality as high as 80% in cases of ruptures, abdominal aortic aneurysm accounts for more than 10,000 deaths in the United States every year. One of the most common treatments is endovascular aneurysm repair, which redirects blood flow away from the aortic wall and bypasses the weak spots by implanting a covered stent graft in the aneurysm sac via a minimally invasive procedure. Among the stent recipients, 30% of them can experience persistent blood flow into the aneurysm sac, called ‘endoleak,’ leading to aneurysm expansion and rupture. Thus, blood pressure and flow near the stent should be periodically monitored. However, the commonly used imaging technique is highly dependent on patient compliance, and its repeatedly administrated iodinated contrast poses a risk of chronic kidney disease. As such, the overall objective of this research is to create a Smart Stent based on a flexible and battery-less membrane-based sensor and wireless bioelectronics with a deep-learning algorithm to realize automated diagnosis of endoleak. This collaborative research will integrate the scientific findings and discoveries with educational venues for students across disciplines (Electrical and Mechanical Engineering), generations (K-12 to lifelong learners), and two institutes (Temple University and Kansas State University).

The overall objective of this research is to develop a Smart Stent for post-endovascular aneurysm repair surveillance that combines a flexible, and battery-less bioelectronic system with a deep-learning algorithm to realize automated diagnosis of endoleak. The central hypothesis is that Smart Stent, created by conformally weaving piezoelectric porous membrane sensors inside and outside of the conventional stent graft, will bring a novel electromechanical wireless biotelemetry scheme whose sensor data can be directly analyzed by a deep-learning model for classification of complex hemodynamics. The intellectual merits of the proposed research include 1) design of an auxetic porous piezoelectric membrane for the Smart Stent that is optimized for the multi-modal sensing of blood pressure and flow, 2) microfabrication  of complex 3D structure and surface-integrated micro coils for near-field magnetic induction communication, 3) a novel electromechanical interrogation scheme that converts energy from physiological information (e.g., blood pressure and flow) into wireless magnetic induction signals, 4) a comprehensive evaluation using a precise aneurysm phantom model to build baseline data for cardiovascular research, and 5) a deep learning-enabled sensing classification algorithm that offers real-time, quantitative, and automated assessment of five different types of endoleak. The research will establish a machine learning-enabled wireless sensing system that will spur new theory and understanding for the next generation implantable biomedical system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

por.por_cntn:
The project "Collaborative Research: Smart Stent for Post-Endovascular Aneurysm Repair Surveillance" focused on developing an innovative medical device, i.e., Smart Stent, to monitor complications arising after endovascular aneurysm repairs (EVAR), a common procedure for treating aneurysms. Traditional follow-up care relies heavily on imaging techniques, which can be costly, invasive, and sometimes unreliable. This research aimed to create a smarter, safer, and more efficient way to monitor patients through wireless, real-time sensing technology combined with artificial intelligence (AI).

Intellectual Merit:

The research successfully created a porous piezoelectric membrane using a material called polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF), engineered with unique pore structures. This design significantly improved the stent’s ability to detect minute changes in blood flow and pressure, vital signs that indicate potential health complications.

A significant achievement was the development of a Smart Stent prototype—a flexible, battery-free, and wireless monitoring device. Using advanced three-dimensional microfabrication techniques, researchers embedded micromachined coils within a cylindrical stent structure, enabling wireless communication through magnetic induction. This means the device can transmit data without batteries, significantly enhancing its practicality and longevity.

To validate its real-world application, the Smart Stent was rigorously tested in a specially designed 3D-printed aneurysm model, accurately simulating human physiological conditions. Results confirmed that the stent could reliably detect and wirelessly transmit pressure fluctuations and blood flow data.

In parallel, researchers developed a sophisticated AI model, employing deep learning techniques, capable of analyzing the data collected by the stent to automatically identify and classify "endoleaks"—a potentially life-threatening complication common after EVAR procedures. The AI demonstrated high accuracy, promising a substantial improvement over traditional diagnostic methods.

Additionally, the project explored self-powered stent technology by investigating piezoelectric energy harvesting from the natural pulsatile motion of blood flow. This innovative approach demonstrated the potential for creating self-sustaining biomedical devices that do not require external power sources, significantly increasing their viability for long-term implantation.

Computational simulations further supported experimental outcomes, demonstrating the device's robust performance under various physiological scenarios and ensuring reliability in clinical settings.

Broader Impacts:

The development of the Smart Stent represents a transformative leap forward in medical technology, potentially improving the quality of life and outcomes for millions of patients undergoing vascular interventions. This innovative approach reduces the need for invasive follow-up procedures and frequent medical imaging, minimizing patient discomfort, exposure to radiation, and healthcare costs.

Beyond healthcare, the principles developed in this research, including wireless communication and energy harvesting technologies, could benefit other fields requiring continuous, autonomous monitoring such as environmental surveillance and remote sensing in harsh conditions.

The project significantly contributed to the education and professional growth of graduate and undergraduate students, equipping them with advanced skills in bioelectronics, machine learning, and microfabrication. These outcomes ensure continued innovation and leadership in biomedical engineering.

Publications stemming from this research have disseminated key findings internationally, influencing ongoing research and development in smart biomedical devices. Future research directions include clinical trials and commercialization efforts to bring this groundbreaking technology to patient care, substantially advancing healthcare diagnostics and management.


Last Modified: 04/22/2025
Modified by: Albert Kim
